title: Emma Carelli
text:
Emma Carelli (12 May 1877 in <a href="Naples">Naples</a> – 17 August 1928 near Rome) was an <a href="Italian%20people">Italian</a> <a href="opera">opera</a>tic <a href="soprano">soprano</a> who was particularly associated with the <a href="dramatic%20soprano">dramatic soprano</a> roles of the <a href="verismo">verismo</a> repertoire and the works of <a href="Richard%20Wagner">Richard Wagner</a>.
After a singing career which lasted almost two decades, she managed the <a href="Teatro%20dell%27Opera%20di%20Roma">Teatro Costanzi</a> in Rome for almost fifteen years. After studying with her father, <a href="Beniamino%20Carelli">Beniamino Carelli</a>, at the <a href="Conservatorio%20San%20Pietro%20a%20Majella">Conservatorio San Pietro a Majella</a>, she made her professional debut in 1895 in the title role of <a href="Saverio%20Mercadante">Mercadante</a>'s "<a href="La%20vestale">La vestale</a>" during the centenary celebrations at <a href="Altamura">Altamura</a> and went on to appear in the opera houses of many Italian cities. In 1898 she married the left-wing politician, self-made millionaire, and later <a href="impresario">impresario</a>, <a href="Walter%20Mocchi">Walter Mocchi</a>.
She sang in several world premieres including: <a href="Pietro%20Floridia">Pietro Floridia</a>'s "<a href="La%20Colonia%20libera">La Colonia libera</a>" (1899); Meryem in <a href="Cesare%20Galeotti">Cesare Galeotti</a>'s "<a href="Anton%20%28opera%29">Anton</a>" (1900) and Rosaura in <a href="Pietro%20Mascagni">Mascagni</a>'s "<a href="Le%20maschere">Le maschere</a>" at <a href="La%20Scala">La Scala</a> in 1901. For several years she also sang in South America, primarily Argentina, as part of a touring troupe organized by her husband. In Buenos Aires (1902) she triumphed in the premiered of "Khrysé" by Arturo Berutti (after Pierre Louys ´s "Aphrodite"), singing the title role. In 1903, she sang the title role in <a href="Edoardo%20Mascheroni">Edoardo Mascheroni</a>'s opera "Lorenza" for its South American premiere in Buenos Aires. She became particularly associated with the title role in <a href="Leoncavallo">Leoncavallo</a>'s "<a href="Zaz%C3%A0">Zazà</a>" and sang in several operas by <a href="Richard%20Wagner">Richard Wagner</a>, including the roles of Kundry in "<a href="Parsifal">Parsifal</a>" and Elisabeth in "<a href="Tannh%C3%A4user%20%28opera%29">Tannhäuser</a>". She also sang the title role in Puccini's "<a href="Tosca">Tosca</a>", the title role in <a href="Umberto%20Giordano">Giordano</a>'s "<a href="Fedora%20%28opera%29">Fedora</a>", Santuzza in Mascagni's "<a href="Cavalleria%20rusticana">Cavalleria rusticana</a>", and Margherita in <a href="Boito">Boito</a>'s "<a href="Mefistofele">Mefistofele</a>" among other roles.
In 1908, Carelli's husband purchased the Teatro Costanzi. His company, Società Teatrale Internazionale, produced the world premiere of <a href="Leoncavallo">Leoncavallo</a>'s "<a href="Maia%20%28opera%29">Maia</a>" during its second season. Carelli took over the management from her husband in 1912 with a new company (Impresa Teatro Costanzi), while he concentrated on running the South American the touring troupe and the Teatro Municipal in Rio de Janeiro and the <a href="Teatro%20Col%C3%B3n">Teatro Colón</a> in Buenos Aires. During her 14-year management of the theatre, several operas received their first Rome performances including <a href="Richard%20Strauss">Richard Strauss</a>'s "<a href="Elektra%20%28opera%29">Elektra</a>" (in which she sang the title role), "<a href="La%20fanciulla%20del%20West">La fanciulla del West</a>", "<a href="Turandot">Turandot</a>" and "<a href="Il%20trittico">Il trittico</a>" by Giacomo Puccini; "<a href="Parsifal">Parsifal</a>" by <a href="Richard%20Wagner">Richard Wagner</a>; "<a href="Francesca%20da%20Rimini">Francesca da Rimini</a>" by <a href="Riccardo%20Zandonai">Riccardo Zandonai</a>; "<a href="Boris%20Godunov%20%28opera%29">Boris Godunov</a>" by <a href="Modest%20Mussorgsky">Modest Mussorgsky</a>; "<a href="Samson%20et%20Dalila">Samson et Dalila</a>" by <a href="Camille%20Saint-Sa%C3%ABns">Camille Saint-Saëns</a>. Apart from Elektra, her only other performance as a singer during that time was in the title role of Mascagni's "<a href="Iris%20%28opera%29">Iris</a>". In 1926, Carelli and Walter Mocchi sold the Costanzi to the Rome City Council and withdrew from most of their other business interests in South America. Carelli died two years later in a car accident. A few years after her death, Mocchi married <a href="Bidu%20Say%C3%A3o">Bidu Sayão</a>, whose career Carelli had fostered.
